title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: There were pre-Bent, Middleton, commissioner, Glencairn, chancellor, DukeHamilton, Montrose, Morton, Eglinton, Lithgow, Callend.-ir. Ncwburgh, Sinclair, Sir James Lockhart of Lee, and Blackhall ; and the report was, being conveened at Glasgow, therevm never a man among them but he was drunk at the time,except only Lee. But when they were sett, the commissionerpropounds the case and the bishop's overture, which all approve except the Lord Lee.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: At Banchory Ternan, a sunny andrural spot, whitened cottages are scattered amongthe larch plantations on the northern bank of thestream, on the opposite side of which, a magnificentamphitheatre of shady groves, and stately forests,embosom the beautiful domain of Blackball, the entrance to which appeared before us, as soon as wehad crossed the rapid and cataractons water of Feuch-This stream rises in lOochnabane, whose prominent nodosity was from hence singularly conspicuous. The lodge of Blackhall is a Grecian screen,on the central arch of which stands a goat, subscribed with the motto of the noble house of Russell, " Che sara sara," though we were told a Mr.Campbell resided in that apparently sweet spot. Immediately beyond the lodge, we crossed the Dee,and entered Banchory Ternan, which we found encircled by every grand component of picturesquescenery.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 10
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: But no, on ChristmasDay--this was Christmas Day!--the pawn-shop would be closed. Suppose hewent to the public-house close by at Blackhall, and offered the watch,which was worth ten pounds, in payment for a meal of bread and cheese? The incongruity was too remarkable; the good folks would either put himto the door, or only let him in to send for the police.

title: The Testament of Gideon Mack
author: Robertson, James
snippet: Jenny was doing a secretarial course there, but she didn't seem tocare about it very much. Her family – her mother, father and ayounger sister – had moved from the south of England when shewas thirteen, and she lived with them out at Blackhall, o

title: Weir of Hermiston :
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Suppose he pawned his watch ? But no, on Christmas-day this was Christmas-day ! the pawn-shop would be closed. Suppose he went to the public-house close by at Blackhall, and offered the watch, which was worth ten pounds, in payment for a meal of bread and cheese ? The incongruity was too remarkable ; the good folks would either put him to the door, or only let him in to send for the police. He turned his pockets out one after another ; some San Francisco  tram-car checks, one cigar, no lights, the pass-key to his father's house, a pocket-handkerchief,  with just a touch of scent : no, money could be raised on none of these.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Ay! and that's e'en true, cummer," said thelame hag, propping herself with a crutch, which supported the shortness of her left leg, " for I mindwhen the father of this Master of Ravenswood thatis now standing before us, sticked young Blackhallwith his whinger, for a wrang word said ower theirwine, or brandy, or what not—he gaed in as lightas a lark, and he came out wi' his feet foremost. Iwas at the winding of the corpse; and when thebluid was washed off, he was a bonnie bouk of man'sbody."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: Imind that, whan I was a lassie, there happened something o' the samekind. My faither had been a tacksman on the estate o' Blackhall; an', asthe land was sour an' wat, an' the seasons for awhile backward, he ayecontrived--for he was a hard-working, carefu' man--to keep us a' in meatand claith, and to meet wi' the factor. But, wae's me! he was sune taenfrae us.
